title: Arch/Fedora — quick pacman/dnf helper aliases
summary: Small shell aliases to speed up package management on Arch (pacman) and Fedora (dnf).
content:
---
title: "Arch/Fedora — quick pacman/dnf helper aliases"
heading: "Arch/Fedora — quick pacman/dnf helper aliases"
icon: "Terminal"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "Small shell aliases to speed up package management on Arch (pacman) and Fedora (dnf)."
tags: ["linux","arch","fedora","bash"]
---

Drop these tiny aliases into `~/.bashrc` or `~/.zshrc` to speed up common package tasks.

```bash
# Arch (pacman)
alias update-system='sudo pacman -Syu --noconfirm'
alias searchpkg='pacman -Ss'

# Fedora (dnf)
alias update-fc='sudo dnf upgrade --refresh -y'
alias search-fc='dnf search'

# Common: clean caches
alias pacman-clean='sudo pacman -Sc --noconfirm'
alias dnf-clean='sudo dnf autoremove -y && sudo dnf clean all'
```

Keep these aliases short and reversible — they're designed for quick daily use and can be removed safely.

title: systemd — run a one-off command in a private slice
summary: Use systemd-run to start a transient service in its own slice with resource limits — great for ad-hoc tasks and benchmarking.
content:
---
title: "systemd — run a one-off command in a private slice"
heading: "systemd — run a one-off command in a private slice"
icon: "Server"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "Use `systemd-run` to create transient services with resource limits — handy for reproducible ad-hoc tests."
tags: ["systemd","linux","cli"]
---

`systemd-run` is great for running a process in an isolated transient unit with runtime limits. Example:

```bash
sudo systemd-run --unit=temp-bench --slice=bench.slice --property=MemoryMax=512M --property=CPUQuota=50% --scope /usr/bin/time -v ./run-my-benchmark.sh
```

This runs `run-my-benchmark.sh` in `bench.slice` with memory and CPU caps so it's easy to repeat tests without creating persistent units.

title: VSCode — handy settings.json snippet
summary: A compact settings.json you can use across machines — format on save, trims, and editor defaults.
content:
---
title: "VSCode — handy settings.json snippet"
heading: "VSCode — handy settings.json snippet"
icon: "VSCode"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "A compact `settings.json` you can use across machines — format on save, trims, and editor defaults."
tags: ["vscode","editor","dotfiles"]
---

Drop this into your `settings.json` for a clean, consistent editor setup across devices:

```json
{
  "editor.formatOnSave": true,
  "files.trimTrailingWhitespace": true,
  "editor.tabSize": 2,
  "editor.detectIndentation": false,
  "editor.minimap.enabled": false,
  "workbench.colorTheme": "Default Dark+",
  "git.enableSmartCommit": true
}
```

Pair with extensions like `esbenp.prettier-vscode`, `ms-vscode.vscode-typescript-next`, and `ms-azuretools.vscode-docker`.

title: Kill process on port (Linux) — quick one-liner
summary: A simple command to find and kill the process listening on a TCP port — works on Arch/Fedora and other Linux systems.
content:
---
title: "Kill process on port (Linux) — quick one-liner"
heading: "Kill process on port (Linux) — quick one-liner"
icon: "Bug"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "One-liners to find and kill the process listening on a given TCP port on Linux."
tags: ["linux","cli","debug"]
---

Quickly find and terminate the process listening on a port (replace 3000):

```bash
sudo fuser -k 3000/tcp || (lsof -i :3000 -t | xargs -r sudo kill -9)
```

This attempts `fuser` first and falls back to `lsof` where `fuser` isn't available. Use with care.

title: ripgrep + fd — fast file search combo
summary: Use `fd` and `rg` together for lightning-fast, colorized search across a codebase.
content:
---
title: "ripgrep + fd — fast file search combo"
heading: "ripgrep + fd — fast file search combo"
icon: "Search"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "Use `fd` and `rg` together for lightning-fast, colorized search across a codebase."
tags: ["cli","search","ripgrep","fd"]
---

`fd` (a fast, user-friendly find) paired with `rg` (ripgrep) makes fast project searching. Example alias:

```bash
alias srch='fd --type f --hidden --exclude .git . | xargs -r rg --line-number --hidden --no-ignore-vcs --colors "match:fg:yellow"'
# usage: srch TODO
```

This includes hidden files while excluding `.git` and adds colored hit highlighting — great for large repos.

title: Neovim minimal Lua config for JS/TS
summary: A small init.lua starter with LSP and a few core plugins for JavaScript/TypeScript development.
content:
---
title: "Neovim minimal Lua config for JS/TS"
heading: "Neovim minimal Lua config for JS/TS"
icon: "Neovim"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "A small `init.lua` starter with LSP and a few core plugins for JavaScript and TypeScript development."
tags: ["neovim","editor","lua"]
---

Keep your Neovim config minimal and fast. Suggested plugins: `nvim-lspconfig`, `nvim-treesitter`, `telescope.nvim` and a fast plugin manager like `lazy.nvim`.

Example note:

```lua
-- plugins.lua (example)
require('lazy').setup({
  'neovim/nvim-lspconfig',
  'nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter',
  'nvim-telescope/telescope.nvim'
})

-- basic lsp attach for typescript
-- require('lspconfig').tsserver.setup({})
```

Start small and add features as you need them; keep startup fast by lazy-loading heavy plugins.

title: SSH config — multiple identities per host
summary: Example `~/.ssh/config` entries for using multiple keys and identities per host (work + personal).
content:
---
title: "SSH config — multiple identities per host"
heading: "SSH config — multiple identities per host"
icon: "Key"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "Example `~/.ssh/config` entries for using multiple keys and identities per host (work + personal)."
tags: ["ssh","dotfiles","git"]
---

Use named entries in `~/.ssh/config` to keep work and personal identities separate.

```text
Host github.com
  HostName github.com
  User git
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_personal
  IdentitiesOnly yes

Host github-work
  HostName github.com
  User git
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_work
  IdentitiesOnly yes
```

Use `git@github-work:owner/repo.git` for your work remote and `git@github.com:owner/repo.git` for personal.

title: Git — rebase into tidy commits (interactive cheat sheet)
summary: A short interactive rebase cheat sheet for cleaning commit history before merge.
content:
---
title: "Git — rebase into tidy commits (interactive cheat sheet)"
heading: "Git — rebase into tidy commits (interactive cheat sheet)"
icon: "Git"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "Interactive rebase quick guide for cleaning up commits before merging a PR."
tags: ["git","workflow","vcs"]
---

Interactive rebase is your friend when you want to clean up history before opening or merging a PR.

```bash
# edit last 5 commits
git rebase -i HEAD~5

# editor commands inside rebase
# pick -> keep as-is
# reword -> change commit message
# edit -> pause and amend
# squash/fixup -> combine commits

# after amend
git add -A && git rebase --continue
```

Keep rebasing small and make a backup branch if you're unsure — interactive rebase rewrites history.

title: jq — pretty filter examples
summary: Common `jq` filters to inspect and transform JSON on the command line.
content:
---
title: "jq — pretty filter examples"
heading: "jq — pretty filter examples"
icon: "JSON"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "Common `jq` filters I use to inspect and manipulate JSON quickly on the command line."
tags: ["jq","cli","json"]
---

Handy `jq` commands for everyday JSON inspection and transformation.

```bash
# pretty print
cat data.json | jq .

# extract array field
cat data.json | jq '.items | map(.name)'

# filter where active is true
cat data.json | jq '.items[] | select(.active == true)'

# compact log-friendly output
cat data.json | jq -c '.items[] | {id, name}'
```

`jq` is indispensable for quick ad-hoc parsing when building or debugging CLI-based data flows.

title: Docker — cleanup & prune safely
summary: Safely clean unused Docker resources — inspect first and prune selectively to avoid surprises.
content:
---
title: "Docker — cleanup & prune safely"
heading: "Docker — cleanup & prune safely"
icon: "Docker"
date: "2025-11-30"
summary: "Safely clean unused Docker resources — inspect first and prune selectively to avoid surprises."
tags: ["docker","cli","cleanup"]
---

Before running a global prune, inspect what's unused and remove only what you expect.

```bash
# inspect usage
docker system df
docker image ls -f dangling=true

# prune safely
docker container prune -f
docker image prune -f
docker volume prune -f
```

Use `docker system prune` only when you know removing networks/volumes/images is safe for your environment.
